statements.text: We should have a single global language.
We shouldn't have a single global language.
A global language would kill diversity of thought and culture.
A global language wouldn't kill diversity of thought and culture.
Within a generation of implementation, vast amounts of culture and literature would be completely inaccessible. This would represent a massive and irreparable rupture with history.
Within a generation of implementation, vast amounts of culture and literature wouldn't be completely inaccessible. This would represent a massive and irreparable rupture with history.
Most culture and literature are already inaccessible today to those who only speak one or two of the 7100 existing languages [1].
Most culture and literature aren't already inaccessible today to those who only speak one or two of the 7100 existing languages [1].
Anything that did not get translated into the new global language by the last native speakers of old languages would be lost.
Anything that did get translated into the new global language by the last native speakers of old languages would be lost.
Efforts could be made to translate all important works as part of the transition to the new language.
Efforts couldn't be made to translate all important works as part of the transition to the new language.
Over time, a single global language would likely increase the number of undecipherable writing systems [2] that our descendants would inherit.
Over time, a single global language wouldn't likely increase the number of undecipherable writing systems [2] that our descendants would inherit.
Machine learning will likely one day be able to decipher [3] any languages that have been lost as a result of this shift to a global language.
Machine learning won't likely one day be able to decipher [3] any languages that have been lost as a result of this shift to a global language.
The existence of a global language does not necessarily involve the eradication of others.
The existence of a global language necessarily involves the eradication of others.
The appropriation of English by various societies has allowed them to integrate the language [4] into their culture, but not necessarily at the expense of their native language.
The appropriation of English by various societies has allowed them to integrate the language [4] into their culture, but necessarily at the expense of their native language.
English is a de facto lingua franca [5], yet it is not destroying language diversity. As long there is not something like an "English language supremacy", a global language won't kill others.
English is a de facto lingua franca [5], yet it is destroying language diversity. As long there is not something like an "English language supremacy", a global language won't kill others.
Languages are being lost at a rate of nine per year [6], and the losses are expected to accelerate over the coming century.
Languages aren't being lost at a rate of nine per year [6], and the losses are expected to accelerate over the coming century.
A global language can coexist with other languages as a universal "second language".
A global language can't coexist with other languages as a universal "second language".

To the extent that there is an Esperanto ideology, it explicitly rejects [7] replacing or subduing national languages. On the contrary, it seeks to provide speakers of different languages a neutral ground, so that one national language does not dominate the other.

To the extent that there is an Esperanto ideology, it explicitly rejectses [7] replacing or subduing national languages. On the contrary, it seeks to provide speakers of different languages a neutral ground, so that one national language does dominate the other.
Similarly, the existing languages could remain as mandatory second languages in their respective countries.
Similarly, the existing languages couldn't remain as mandatory second languages in their respective countries.
Over time, it is possible that people will become too lazy to learn more than one language and default to the global language for convenience.
Over time, it isn't possible that people will become too lazy to learn more than one language and default to the global language for convenience.
The past centuries have seen several languages die out [8] as a few dominant languages reduce people's incentive to maintain minority languages.
The past centuries haven't seen several languages die out [8] as a few dominant languages reduce people's incentive to maintain minority languages.
Using different languages teaches people to think in different ways [9]. Using a single global language would harm this diversity of thought.
Using different languages doesn't teach people to think in different ways [9]. Using a single global language would harm this diversity of thought.
This would lead to the homogenisation of society, whereby a single culture would win out over all others.
This wouldn't lead to the homogenisation of society, whereby a single culture would win out over all others.
This is a good thing, as diversity in language and culture is divisive.
This is a good thing, as diversity in language and culture isn't divisive.
Diversity is inevitable but deliberately embracing it prevents it being divisive.
Diversity isn't inevitable but deliberately embracing it prevents it being divisive.
By being mindful of diversity awareness [10], people can overcome divisive issues and use diversity to their advantage.
By being mindful of diversity awareness [10], people can't overcome divisive issues and use diversity to their advantage.
Language barriers create culture clashes [11].
Language barriers don't create culture clashes [11].
Having a singular culture would likely eliminate harmful cultural practices like female genital mutilation [12] or honor killings [13].
Having a singular culture wouldn't likely eliminate harmful cultural practices like female genital mutilation [12] or honor killings [13].
These practices can be eliminated without destroying all cultural diversity.
These practices can't be eliminated without destroying all cultural diversity.
A language is far more than just a collection of words or sounds to express a message. A language is identity [14], culture [15], and is what makes our world so rich and diverse.
A language isn't far more than just a collection of words or sounds to express a message. A language is identity [14], culture [15], and is what makes our world so rich and diverse.
Culture is expressed in a myriad of ways - art, dance, architecture - which are not dependent on language.
Culture is expressed in a myriad of ways - art, dance, architecture - which are dependent on language.
Many forms of visual art are considered a type of universal language [16] themselves.
Many forms of visual art aren't considered a type of universal language [16] themselves.
Language is used to partition reality [17] into concepts. Different languages provoke different partitionings, which can be more or less suitable to solve thought problems.
Language isn't used to partition reality [17] into concepts. Different languages provoke different partitionings, which can be more or less suitable to solve thought problems.
Americans, British and Australians speak the same language, yet they have diversity [18] of thought [19] and culture [20].
Americans, British and Australians don't speak the same language, yet they have diversity [18] of thought [19] and culture [20].

Polyglots have a greater capacity [21] to learn new information and process information in different ways. Having only one language could decrease this function of the brain, which could lead to a lack of innovation and creativity.

Polyglots don't have a greater capacity [21] to learn new information and process information in different ways. Having only one language could decrease this function of the brain, which could lead to a lack of innovation and creativity.
One simple global language, easily learned in addition to one's native tongue, would increase the chance of everyone having bilingual brains.
One simple global language, easily didn't learn in addition to one's native tongue, would increase the chance of everyone having bilingual brains.

Although computer programming languages do not work exactly the same way as natural languages, they also help maintain [22] these neurological functions. In the future, programming languages will be at least partly responsible for keeping the brain fit.

Although computer programming languages do work exactly the same way as natural languages, they also help maintain [22] these neurological functions. In the future, programming languages will be at least partly responsible for keeping the brain fit.

This assumes the greater capacity to learn new information was caused by knowing the second language. It could equally be the case that the greater capacity caused them to learn the second language, or a third factor that caused both.

This doesn't assume the greater capacity to learn new information was caused by knowing the second language. It could equally be the case that the greater capacity caused them to learn the second language, or a third factor that caused both.
Studies have shown [23] that learning another language may delay the onset of Alzheimer's disease. Eliminating this possibility may result in more Alzheimer's related issues for society.
Studies haven't shown [23] that learning another language may delay the onset of Alzheimer's disease. Eliminating this possibility may result in more Alzheimer's related issues for society.

A single global language wouldn't greatly benefit culture, as it would further encourage people from different cultures to interact and share ideas.

A equal linguistic footing between cultures wouldn't lead to greater equality of opportunity [24] around the world.

A single global language wouldn't curb the current advantage [25] of native English speakers in industry, science, academia, etc.
Current scientific knowledge is biased [26] towards evidence published in English.
Current scientific knowledge isn't biased [26] towards evidence published in English.
Scientists and academics will still have to cite [27] existing English language research after the implementation of a global language.
Scientists and academics won't still have to cite [27] existing English language research after the implementation of a global language.

The earliest adopters of the language wouldn't have an advantage over others that could result in lasting disparity.
If a global language is taken from an existing language, the original native speakers would have an advantage.
If a global language is taken from an existing language, the original native speakers wouldn't have an advantage.

The global language would likely be built around the grammatical structures of majority languages. Speakers of minority languages would face higher burdens to learning the global language which would make no difference to the status quo.

The global language wouldn't likely be built around the grammatical structures of majority languages. Speakers of minority languages would face higher burdens to learning the global language which would make no difference to the status quo.
A single global language can lead to a deeper understanding between different cultures, facilitating global peace.
A single global language can't lead to a deeper understanding between different cultures, facilitating global peace.

Implementation of a global language wouldn't require international collaboration and could lead to better interactions between countries, peoples, and groups.
Our perspectives, needs, and struggles can be understood by others more clearly instead of getting lost in translation.
Our perspectives, needs, and struggles can't be understood by others more clearly instead of getting lost in translation.
International students would be able to study abroad without any language barriers.
International students wouldn't be able to study abroad without any language barriers.
It is also likely that negotiations on the manner of implementation could strain relations between various groups.
It isn't also likely that negotiations on the manner of implementation could strain relations between various groups.
Empathy between humans happens through communication and requires language [28].
Empathy between humans doesn't happen through communication and requires language [28].
A single language would allow hate groups to organize more effectively.
A single language wouldn't allow hate groups to organize more effectively.
Neo-Nazi groups exist in countries around the world [29]. If they all spoke the same language, they could more easily spread their message and coordinate.
Neo-Nazi groups don't exist in countries around the world [29]. If they all spoke the same language, they could more easily spread their message and coordinate.

A single global language wouldn't be beneficial in terms of efficiency.
International trade and cooperation would become easier, which would be beneficial for the global economy.
International trade and cooperation wouldn't become easier, which would be beneficial for the global economy.

A single global language None speak in a diversified culture is analogous to a single technological standard [30] that is compatible and understood across different market brands.

Standardization doesn't have multiple benefits [31] in terms of efficiency and understanding.
Assuming international cooperation would improve by speaking the same language is a fallacy; nearly all Americans speak the same language, yet they still have disagreements [32].
Not Assuming international cooperation would improve by speaking the same language is a fallacy; nearly all Americans speak the same language, yet they still have disagreements [32].

More international trade couldn't lead to more harmful effects on the environment.

If all climate scientists and environmental activists spoke the same language, it isn't more likely that they could effectively organize ways to combat climate change.

Climate activists aren't already overcoming language barriers by voluntarily translating [33] climate-related literature into various languages.

Increasing the effects of globalization [34] isn't likely to intensify human's negative impacts on the environment.

International communication won't be faster, which means more time to invest in other activities.
Firms could save money on translators and interpreters, instead directing that money elsewhere.

With one global language, people won't be able to communicate with each other regardless of where they are from.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This process would likely take hundreds of years, during which time the benefits of a global language would be realized.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Esperanto has been in use for over a century and very little lexical change has occurred.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Esperanto is a niche language with few native speakers [81]. A truly globalized language would evolve more quickly.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Some languages, such as Icelandic [82], evolve very slowly, allowing modern day people to connect with their ancestors' writings from more than a thousand years ago.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Even if humans did create a global language and made it mandatory, not every member of the human race would be able or willing to learn it.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This argument pedantically exaggerates what is meant by 'single global language'. If the vast majority of the world’s population speaks it, we should consider the goal achieved.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Not all people would accept the imposition of the new language.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Historians and people who are passionate about learning extinct languages would keep the old languages alive.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Attempts to resurrect [83] near-extinct languages as living languages typically fail without significant motive beyond antiquarian interest and even then do not resurrect them as they once were.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: After a few generations, people would naturally agree to learn the new language, as not knowing it would likely limit their educational, economic, and social opportunities.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Some people might feel that a new language would impede upon their identity and traditions.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A global language could not be truly universal, as deaf people use sign language, and blind people use braille.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Deaf and blind people still understand languages like anyone else, they just have different methods of expressing or consuming that language. The same would apply to a global language.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is a braille alphabet for different languages, including English [84], Esperanto [85], and Chinese [86]. A braille system could be similarly adopted for any global language.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The global language could be a sign language. A sign language can be used by blind people also, by using tactile signing.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The creation of a single global language is not possible because it is too difficult to reach every individual with this concept.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is not yet free internet access [87] all over the world and limited resources for travel and the distribution of learning materials.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is a lack of communication between different peoples that will make it impossible to have every individual in the world speak the same language.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Different peoples do not need to talk to each other to implement a global language as long as governments can agree to promote the language within their territories.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Given enough time, it is possible for everyone to be made familiar with the global language.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The existence of languages like Spanish [88] and English [89] in multiple continents shows that language can be successfully spread and maintained across great distances and times.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Both Spanish [90] and English [91] came to the Americas hundreds of years ago, and yet these languages can still be understood by native speakers around the world, despite varieties in local dialects.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many achievements that were previously thought impractical or impossible were realized through concerted effort.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: For thousands of years people believed that traveling to the moon was a fantasy that belonged in the realm of science fiction [92].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are also countless examples [93] of impractical endeavors that were undertaken, only to fail.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Humans could use the implementation of a global language to construct [94] a better language for everyone.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Esperanto [95] is proof that an efficient, global language can be developed.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Esperanto has 16 grammar rules [96], applied without exception, which makes it more simple.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Esperanto has an ingenious system for constructing words [97] from essential building blocks, which allows for complexity and rapid expansion of vocabulary.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Esperanto's vocabulary is based on various existing language groups, making it relatable.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Esperanto is only relatable to speakers of European languages, which biases [98] them in favor of Asian or African language speakers.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Esperanto is too basic and doesn't convey complex ideas well.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The power of expressing complex ideas is the same for Esperanto as for natural languages, as demonstrated by the amount of original Esperanto literature [99], some of which was nominated for the Nobel prize [100].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many famous books have been translated [101] into Esperanto, which wouldn't have been possible if it didn't express complex ideas well.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are a very limited number of root words [102] in Esperanto, compared to the hundreds of thousands [103] of words in languages like English.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Esperanto is proof that even if you develop a "better" language, it will probably remain niche.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Esperanto is already well-established. There are organized speakers of the language in 120+ countries, and the Universala Kongreso [104] gathers, on average, 2000 Esperantists every year.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This is almost nothing compared to the goal of having an universal world language.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Starting over with a new language isn't going to get humanity closer to the goal either. Either we need to develop and support Esperanto or give up on this project.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Esperanto and other universal languages have remained niche as there is no push from large international institutions such as the UN to implement a constructed universal language.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The League of Nations in 1924 unanimously recommended [105] that countries support the language’s development, showing the feasibility of gaining support from a supranational body politic. Yet even with such support, Esperanto failed to catch on.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The single case of Esperanto is not sufficient evidence that other constructed languages might not be more successful.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Despite existing for more than a century, Esperanto only has around a thousand native speakers [106] today.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Creating a new language other than Esperanto would alienate the Esperanto community [107], who arguably has the most enthusiasm of all for the dispersion of a neutral, global language.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Any claim that one language or language feature is "better" than another is completely subjective.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Any attempt to define criteria by which a new, artificial language could be "better" than all other languages would necessarily privilege some cultural patterns over others.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is possible for a language to be objectively better. The main goal of a language is to convey thoughts and feelings. A language can be better or worse at this.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Languages have a variety of design features which objectively impact communicative efficiency, including learning time.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many languages [108], including English [109], have exceptionally irregular spelling systems that make them more difficult to learn.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Creating a universal language and spreading its use worldwide is a disproportionate effort for something that doesn't represent a real problem.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It doesn't represent a real problem to English speakers, as English is the language of privilege [110]. The vast majority of non-English-speaking global citizens would likely disagree.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Fostering bilingualism through the continued spreading of English worldwide is easier and will preserve diverse cultures and languages better.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many widely spoken languages already overcome language barriers successfully.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The European Commission’s DG Translation costs 330 million euro per year. [111] Having one global language would allow this money to be spent on better things.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: English is already the dominant global language [112] for international trade and cooperation, as well as research.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: People already make the effort of learning languages to communicate with those who don't speak their language.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: As language learning is time intensive [113], giving language learners the best return on investment for that time and money is justified.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Society is not obligated to compensate people for actions that they undertake voluntarily.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This time and effort could be better spent on other activities if everyone spoke the same language.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many languages include a sexist and binary view of gender [114]. A new language could be more equal and allow people to more easily talk about those with non-binary gender.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Existing languages are finding ways to change their language [115] to be more gender inclusive.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: These changes have brought about fierce resistance [116] by language traditionalists.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Sexism is built in [117] to many languages, which can have harmful effects on women in these societies.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A language with an easier writing and spelling system would benefit people with dyslexia and other learning issues.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Dyslexia is found [118] even in languages without alphabets, so it is unlikely that the creation of a new language will significantly benefit these people.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Dyslexia varies in nature and presentation across speakers of different languages [119], to the point where it almost constitutes a different condition. As such, a singular language would not be able to benefit everyone equally.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Learning foreign languages [120] can be incredibly challenging for those with dyslexia. A singular global language would remove this barrier for communication.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If we want to have a single global language, it's so much easier to choose an existing language than to construct a new one.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The creation of a new language could involve the whole world. This kind of an open source project would allow for the world's various cultures to have a sense of agency over the process and resulting language.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Choosing an existing language is inherently unfair, as it privileges the existing native speakers.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Choosing a widely spoken language like English would limit the number of people who have to learn it and thus the amount of resources involved.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is already a great deal of existing English language instruction infrastructure, expertise, and materials [121] available for use (p 9).
